author: By Claire Moses
title: Object Found on Australian Beach Is a Mystery No More
description: A cylindrical object that was found in remote Western Australia probably came from an Indian rocket, Australia’s space agency said.
content: A mysterious cylindrical object found on a remote Australian beach this month is a piece of debris from an Indian rocket, Australia’s space agency announced on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka and Lauren McCarthy
title: Angus Cloud, Actor on ‘Euphoria,’ Dies at 25
description: The cause of death was not released, but his family said that he had “intensely struggled” after the recent death of his father.
content: Angus Cloud, the actor best known for portraying Fezco, a lovable drug dealer on the HBO television show “Euphoria,” died on Monday at his family home in Oakland, Calif. He was 25.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Disney Goes Back to the Future
description: Robert Iger has reportedly brought in two former heirs apparent, Kevin Mayer and Thomas Staggs, for advice, renewing focus on succession at the media giant.
content: Things aren’t getting easier for Disney’s Robert Iger, including yet another poor showing at the box office this weekend. So reports that the media giant’s C.E.O. has brought back two former heirs apparent, Kevin Mayer and Tom Staggs, to advise on the future of Disney’s legacy TV businesses were sure to get Hollywood talking.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Callie Holtermann and Amir Hamja
title: What We Saw on the Beyoncé Express
description: Dressed in their “Renaissance” best, fans flooded New Jersey Transit to catch the superstar’s pair of performances at MetLife Stadium this weekend.
content: Several cowboy hats tipped upward toward the departures board at Penn Station, their wearers unusually excited to board a crowded, sweaty train to New Jersey.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: What Makes a Long-Distance Swimmer Tick?
description: Lewis Pugh loves the Hudson River so much that he plans to swim all 315 miles of it, from the Adirondacks to New York City.
content: Good morning. It’s Monday. Today we’ll hear from an endurance swimmer who is bringing his Speedo, his goggles and his cap to the Hudson River. His goal is more than just bragging rights for making his way through the Hudson from beginning to end, 315 miles in all.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren McCarthy
title: Dogs Die From Heat-Related Injuries on Their Way to Police Training
description: The German shepherds were en route from Chicago to Michigan City, Ind., when the air-conditioning unit in the vehicle in which they were being transported failed, the police said.
content: German shepherds that were being transported from Chicago to a training center for police dogs in Michigan City, Ind., died in the heat on Thursday after an air-conditioning unit that was being used to keep the animals cool failed, the local authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Zinoman
title: In Pee-wee Herman, Joy and Fun Got Flat-Out Weird
description: Paul Reubens committed to profound silliness without ever going mean or dark — though some peers were disappointed that he focused on one character.
content: Of all the great flesh-and-blood cartoons of 1980s popular culture — Hulk Hogan, Madonna, Mr. T — the one easiest for small children to relate to was Pee-wee Herman. He made the same kind of obnoxious jokes we did (“I know you are but what am I?”), in a similar, if more overtly nasal, squeak while capturing an un-self-conscious exuberance that felt deeply familiar.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Paul Reubens, Creator of Pee-wee Herman, Is Dead at 70
description: With his bow tie, short drainpipe pants and flattop hairdo, Pee-wee became enshrined in the popular imagination as a symbol of childlike whimsy.
content: Paul Reubens, the comic actor whose bow-tied, childlike alter-ego Pee-wee Herman became an unlikely if almost uncategorizable movie and television sensation in the 1980s, died on Sunday in Los Angeles. He was 70.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy
title: Europe’s Economy Expanded in Spring, and Inflation Has Eased
description: The eurozone economy grew more than expected, while inflation slowed after a string of rate hikes from the European Central Bank.
content: Europe’s economy showed signs of recovery in spring, emerging from a stagnant start to the year to expand in the months of April to June, data released on Monday showed. What’s more, the annual rate of inflation eased in July.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Elie
title: Looking at Early Christianity Through a Different Lens
description: In “Christendom,” the medievalist Peter Heather takes on a crucial millennium.
content: In 1987, the Oxford professor Robin Lane Fox published “Pagans and Christians,” a landmark narrative history of late antiquity, focused on a moment that Fox called, memorably, “the point at which the ancient world still touches ours directly.” That turning point involved the conversion of the Roman emperor Constantine, in A.D. 312, and the acceptance of Christianity as the state religion of the empire.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: Biden Spoke With Son’s Associates, but Not About Business, Former Partner Says
description: Republicans accused the president of lying, while Democrats said the testimony of Devon Archer, who worked with Hunter Biden, showed that his son was selling the illusion of access to his father.
content: President Biden met with and spoke to his son Hunter’s international business associates on a number of occasions over a decade as Hunter Biden sought to drum up consulting deals, including while his father was vice president, his former business partner told Congress on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Monday Briefing
description: Drone attacks in Moscow.
content: The Russian Defense Ministry said that Ukrainian forces had fired at least three drones at Moscow, the latest in a wave of attacks in Russia; one of them was destroyed in Odintsovo, outside Moscow. Two others struck commercial buildings in the capital after being intercepted by Russian air defenses, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catrin Einhorn and Jason Gulley
title: A Desperate Push to Save Florida’s Coral: Get It Out of the Sea
description: Teams dedicated to ocean restoration are urgently moving samples to tanks on land as a marine heat wave devastates entire reefs.
content: When Bailey Thomasson first spotted the coral, she felt a jolt of relief. She was diving for samples off the Florida Keys, and the thicket of elkhorn coral below looked brown, not the stark white that would indicate bleaching from the record-breaking sea temperatures in the area. But as she swam closer, she realized the situation was far worse than she’d considered possible.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: A Fast, Fresh Pasta for Those Perfect Peak Tomatoes
description: Grating your tomatoes preserves their juicy acidity, which sings when swirled into hot garlic oil with handfuls of basil.
content: August starts tomorrow, which means summer is at least halfway over and it’s high time to ask yourself: Have I eaten enough tomatoes? The correct answer, of course, is “most certainly not.” Ham El-Waylly is here to remedy this with his new recipe for grated tomato pasta (above).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Bradsher
title: China Is Trying to Make Its Gloomy Consumers Spend More
description: The central government listed measures aimed at prodding people to open up their wallets, but absent was how much it will spend to support the stimulus plan.
content: Chinese drivers who trade in older cars for newer models will be eligible for subsidies, as will rural households that buy insulation and other home renovation materials to improve energy efficiency. Entrance fees at scenic sites will be cut to promote tourism.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. Edward Moreno
title: A New Worry for Mexicans in the U.S.: The Strong Peso
description: The peso’s soaring value means the money that Mexicans in the United States send home doesn’t go as far as it used to.
content: Most of the money that Antonio Solis makes delivering food on his motorcycle in New York City will eventually make its way to Monterrey, Mexico, where it will pay for his family’s mortgage, his daughter’s college tuition and daily expenses like groceries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: Liz Kingsman Is Doing a One-Woman Show (Without Kit Harington)
description: The comedian talks about her slightly goofy, slightly surreal style, and why New York has proved to be “the hardest translation” yet.
content: When it came time to create a trailer for her one-woman show — which is titled, of all things, “One Woman Show” and is playing at the Greenwich House Theater — Liz Kingsman researched what other productions had done. One video especially made her laugh.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Cohen
title: Why One Country Is Struggling to Break Away From Russian Gas
description: Austria, unlike most European Union countries, is still buying nearly as much natural gas from Russia as it was before the war in Ukraine.
content: In the 17 months since Moscow ordered soldiers into Ukrainian territory, countries across Europe have moved with surprising speed to reduce their longstanding dependence on cheap Russian gas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: The Economic Case for Taxing Star Athletes
description: How much professional athletes should earn is more than a simple question of supply and demand.
content: OK, it’s time for another round of “Are Star Athletes Overpaid?” I hope to bring some economic theory to bear on this well-worn question. As usual, which side you take will say a lot more about you than it says about the star athletes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jillian Weinberger
title: The Fear I Felt When I Was Told My Daughter Looked Perfect
description: What the science says about the heritability of disordered eating.
content: When the sonographer told us we were having a girl, I panicked.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Mazzetti, Ronen Bergman and Adam Goldman
title: Who Paid for a Mysterious Spy Tool? The F.B.I., an F.B.I. Inquiry Found.
description: After a Times report, the bureau canceled its contract with a government contractor that used the tool on its behalf. But questions remain.
content: When The New York Times reported in April that a contractor had purchased and deployed a spying tool made by NSO, the contentious Israeli hacking firm, for use by the U.S. government, White House officials said they were unaware of the contract and put the F.B.I. in charge of figuring out who might have been using the technology.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Salam
title: The Best True Crime to Stream: Serial Killers, With Less Glorification
description: Four picks across television, documentary and podcast that do a lot more than rehash what we already know about notorious killers.
content: Decades before true crime crept in from the margins and inundated pop culture, I found a humble paperback buried in the stacks of my parents’ bookshelf about America’s most notorious serial killers. Perhaps inadvisable for a 10 year old, I read and reread about the horrors inflicted by, among others, Ed Gein, John Wayne Gacy and Ted Bundy. Though I was already aware that terrible things happened in general, this was different: specific, personal and intimately chilling.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Tuesday Briefing: Floods Pummel Beijing
description: Also, evidence shows that Myanmar’s junta has increased its brutal attacks against civilians.
content: Fierce rain and flooding pummeled Beijing yesterday, killing at least two people as the downpour triggered landslides and swept away cars on the city’s outskirts. The authorities issued a red alert for what they warned was the heaviest deluge in years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Alter
title: Obsessed With the Ocean, Susan Casey Takes the Plunge
description: Susan Casey has long been enchanted by the deep ocean. For her book “The Underworld,” she finally got to visit that unforgiving landscape herself.
content: Some writers go to the ends of the earth in pursuit of a great story. Susan Casey went to the bottom of the ocean.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei and Alan Feuer
title: Trump Employee Released on Bond After Court Appearance in Documents Case
description: Carlos De Oliveira, the Mar-a-Lago property manager, made his first court appearance on charges of conspiring with Donald J. Trump to obstruct the retrieval of classified material.
content: Carlos De Oliveira, the property manager of Mar-a-Lago, former President Donald J. Trump’s private club and residence in Florida, appeared in court for the first time on Monday to face charges of conspiring with Mr. Trump to obstruct the government’s monthslong efforts to retrieve highly sensitive national security documents from the former president after he left office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennie Erin Smith
title: Mauricio Diazgranados Is a Botanist in a Hurry
description: For the first time, the New York Botanical Garden has a chief scientist who hails from the same region as so much of its collections.
content: Frailejones are oversized members of the sunflower family with thick stems and crowns of pointed, hairy leaves. Shrouded in the mists of cold, wet, nearly treeless tropical highlands called páramos, they evoke the Spanish monks for which they are named.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley
title: The Brains Behind Netanyahu’s Judicial Overhaul
description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel is the face of his government’s effort to reduce judicial power. His justice minister, Yariv Levin, is the main architect.
content: When Israeli lawmakers passed a deeply contentious law last Monday to weaken the Supreme Court, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu did not linger in the voting chamber to celebrate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Sperling
title: To Keep TV Shows Afloat, Some Networks Are Cutting Actors’ Pay
description: In a shrinking business, actors on some shows are being guaranteed less money, an issue that’s helping to fuel the Hollywood strike.
content: Starring on the CBS sitcom “Bob Hearts Abishola” has been good for Bayo Akinfemi. Being a regular cast member for four years has given him financial security and made him a star in his native Nigeria, where the show is wildly popular. It even helped him branch out from acting, when producers gave him the opportunity to direct an episode.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Poniewozik
title: I Loved ‘Pee-wee’s Playhouse’ Enough to Marry It
description: Paul Reubens’s oddball masterpiece celebrated the kind of anarchy that captivates kids and freaks out adults.
content: “Pee-wee’s Playhouse” premiered on CBS in 1986, the year I graduated from high school, which means I was probably too old for it. Or maybe too young. Or possibly just right.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By German Lopez
title: An Enemy in Mexico
description: Republicans are embracing a potential act of war against Mexico.
content: Mexico has been one of America’s closest allies for years under both Democratic and Republican administrations, even Donald Trump’s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Ley
title: How a Congestion Pricing Windfall Could Upgrade the Subways
description: Money collected from a plan to toll drivers could be used to make changes to New York City’s subway system, including adding elevators, fare gates and platform barriers.
content: A long and expensive wish list to upgrade New York City’s subway system is about to get a multibillion-dollar investment from the state’s much-contested plan to toll drivers for entering Midtown Manhattan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed
title: British Government Signals Support for Oil and Gas Industry
description: With a general election expected next year, the government said it would issue new licenses for energy exploration in the North Sea.
content: The British government said Monday that it would issue “hundreds” of new licenses for oil and natural gas exploration in the North Sea, as concerns about energy security and jobs at least momentarily outweigh efforts to address climate change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Campbell Robertson
title: Jury in Pittsburgh Synagogue Trial to Begin Deliberating Death Penalty
description: After finding the gunman guilty of deadly hate crimes, the jurors now must decide whether to vote for a death sentence.
content: Testimony concluded on Monday in the federal trial of the man who killed 11 worshipers in a Pittsburgh synagogue, as the defense and prosecution laid out, in their closing arguments, the conflict at the heart of the case: whether the man who carried out the massacre was driven by a cold, calculated hatred or by a diseased mind.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valerie Hopkins
title: Moscow’s attacks are stoking hatred of Russia in Odesa.
description: Standing on a bridge overlooking the road to Odesa’s main port, Nina Sulzhenko surveyed the damage wrought by a recent Russian missile strike: The House of Scientists, one of the Ukrainian city’s best-loved buildings, was in shambles. The mansion’s destroyed gardens spilled down over a ruined residential complex, and burned bricks lay strewn across the sidewalk.
content: Standing on a bridge overlooking the road to Odesa’s main port, Nina Sulzhenko surveyed the damage wrought by a recent Russian missile strike: The House of Scientists, one of the Ukrainian city’s best-loved buildings, was in shambles. The mansion’s destroyed gardens spilled down over a ruined residential complex, and burned bricks lay strewn across the sidewalk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Nehamas
title: DeSantis Jabs at Trump’s Legal Trouble as He Resets His Campaign
description: Ron DeSantis’s remarks to a voter in New Hampshire suggest he may step up his attacks against the man who leads him in national polls by a wide margin.
content: Two days after former President Donald J. Trump used a demeaning nickname to describe Ron DeSantis to a packed hall of Iowa Republican activists, Mr. DeSantis pointedly invoked the federal indictment against his chief rival, saying that if Mr. Trump had “drained the swamp like he promised,” then he probably “wouldn’t be in the mess that he’s in right now.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anatoly Kurmanaev
title: A Spending Boom Fuels Russia’s Wartime Economy, Raising Bubble Fears
description: The economic strength has helped to maintain popular support for Vladimir Putin’s war, but some have warned the state-led spending is threatening the country’s financial stability.
content: After Russia invaded Ukraine, Anna, a Russian entrepreneur, made a snap decision to open a real estate agency, hoping to create a safety net from the economic fallout of the conflict. The career change has paid off.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Goldberg
title: The Radicalization of the Young Right
description: These days, young reactionaries find their inspiration not in the adolescent superman fantasies of Ayn Rand but in the nihilistic Joker energy of 4chan.
content: In December 2021, the podcast “Know Your Enemy” — billed as a leftist’s guide to the conservative movement — welcomed Nate Hochman, a young man whom the host Sam Adler-Bell described as “the boy wonder of the new right.” At the time, Hochman was a 23-year-old National Review writer who’d already cycled through several of the prestigious fellowships available to aspiring young conservative intellectuals. (He’d later contribute to The New York Times.) Matthew Sitman, Adler-Bell’s co-host and a former conservative himself, considered Hochman a friend, and on the podcast, Hochman mostly came across as thoughtful and reasonable, eager to find the places where left- and right-leaning critics of liberalism agree.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Dorothy Tapper Goldman, Who Sold Rare Copy of Constitution, Dies at 78
description: The document, one of 13 known copies from the original printing, was auctioned off for a record $43.3 million, which financed her philanthropy.
content: Dorothy Tapper Goldman, a philanthropist and major collector of American historical documents who in 2021 sold her original printed copy of the U.S. Constitution, which her husband had bought in 1988 for $165,000, for a record-setting $43.2 million, died on July 23 at her home in Manhattan. She was 78.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: The Gaps Get Smaller as the World Cup Gets Larger
description: Expanding the Women’s World Cup was a good idea. Just not for the reasons FIFA thinks.
content: Given where the journey had started and where it had led, it was no wonder that watching the Philippines win a game at the Women’s World Cup felt as if it defied rational explanation, even to those involved.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma G. Fitzsimmons and Jay Root
title: Migrants Will Sleep Outdoors Because ‘There Is No More Room,’ Adams Says
description: Mayor Eric Adams said New York has run out of shelter space for migrants, and he defended a troubled contractor working with the city on its response.
content: The images outside the Roosevelt Hotel in Midtown Manhattan early Monday were stark: Scores of migrants huddled in a line stretching more than a block, some still sleeping as they waited to be processed in New York City’s intake center.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Kenigsberg
title: Three Great Documentaries to Stream
description: This month’s picks include a Vietnam War portrait, an analysis of Los Angeles as a film subject and a look into the admissions process for an elite film school.
content: The proliferation of documentaries on streaming services makes it difficult to choose what to watch. Each month, we’ll choose three nonfiction films — classics, overlooked recent docs and more — that will reward your time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Goldilocks and the Bidenomics Bears
description: Biden didn’t want to do too little, and may not have done too much.
content: It’s hard to overstate how good the U.S. economic news has been lately. It was so good that it didn’t just raise hopes for the future; it led to widespread rethinking of the past. Basically, Bidenomics, widely reviled and ridiculed a year ago, looks a lot better in retrospect. It’s starting to look as if the administration got it mostly right, after all.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
title: The Biden Family Drama Is Far From Over
description: And it’s not because of Commander’s biting.
content: Gail Collins: Bret, I suspect our first big argument today will be about Hunter Biden. But I feel sorta obliged to start with Donald Trump. I mean, how often do you have a former president facing the threat of multiple indictments on alleged transgressions ranging from paying hush money over a sex scandal to prompting a riot that stormed the Capitol to trying to fix an election?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nate Cohn
title: Why Trump Is So Hard to Beat
description: The first Times/Siena poll of the G.O.P. primary shows he still commands a seemingly unshakable base of loyal supporters.
content: In the half century of modern presidential primaries, no candidate who led his or her nearest rival by at least 20 points at this stage has ever lost a party nomination.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher
title: Trump Crushing DeSantis and G.O.P. Rivals, Times/Siena Poll Finds
description: The twice-indicted former president leads across nearly every category and region, as primary voters wave off concerns about his escalating legal jeopardy.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump is dominating his rivals for the Republican presidential nomination, leading his nearest challenger, Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida, by a landslide 37 percentage points nationally among the likely Republican primary electorate, according to the first New York Times/Siena College poll of the 2024 campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alisha Haridasani Gupta
title: The Persistent Confusion Around the U.T.I.
description: Much of the advice about urinary tract infections isn’t rooted in science. Here are four misunderstood facts about this very common affliction.
content: Over half of women in the United States will get a urinary tract infection in their lifetime. (This is compared to an estimated 14 percent of men.) Despite being common, it is often an experience layered with frustration and stigma, said Dr. Kalpana Gupta, a professor at Boston University Chobanian & Avedisian School of Medicine who does research on U.T.I.s. Patients “feel some personal responsibility,” she said. “Like, ‘I’m doing something wrong.’”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Donald Trump Is Polling Far Ahead of His G.O.P. Rivals
description: Also, a push to save Florida’s coral. Here’s the latest at the end of Monday.
content: A dozen Republicans are campaigning to secure their party’s nomination in next year’s presidential election. But the race between them is not remotely close, according to a New York Times/Siena College poll that was released today. Donald Trump leads his next closest challenger, Ron DeSantis, by 37 percentage points. No other candidate topped 3 percent.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Extreme Heat Is Costly Drain on Productivity
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, July 31, 2023.
content: “Two times this summer I’ve had heart palpitations from the heat, and left work early to go to the E.R.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valeriya Safronova
title: Dancing Till Dawn on the Albanian Riviera
description: A weeklong music-and-wellness festival on the beach is just one reason visitors are now flocking to a country that was sealed off to the world for decades.
content: More than a dozen sweaty people in various states of undress giggled as a capoeira instructor directed us to crawl around on the floor. Make eye contact, he told us as we tried to follow the flow of one another’s bodies. But it was hard not to stare at the sparkling blue Ionian Sea.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Cherelus
title: Don’t Worry, He’s All Right, According to at Least One Woman
description: Facebook groups like Vouched Dating and Are We Dating the Same Guy? help strangers vet potential partners.
content: These days the idea of meeting a perfect stranger doesn’t quite hold the romantic allure it once did (if it ever really did at all). Especially when it comes to online dating. Before apps like Tinder, it was common for people to meet potential mates in their neighborhood, or through school, work or religious institutions. The internet, however, provides a much larger dating pool, which can reduce the chances of two people having mutual friends.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dani Blum
title: Alcohol-Related Deaths Are Rising Among Women
description: The gap between male and female fatalities is narrowing, including for people 65 and older. Here’s how to know if you need to cut back on your drinking.
content: A new study shows that alcohol-related deaths among women are rising at a faster rate than those among men, particularly for people 65 and older.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Nechepurenko
title: Wagner Mercenary Group Will Pause Recruiting, New Recording Says
description: The recording, purportedly of the group’s founder, Yevgeny V. Prigozhin, appeared to signal that the mercenary force would continue operations but on a smaller scale.
content: A social media account linked to Russia’s Wagner private military company has posted a recording purportedly of the mercenary group’s leader saying that it would pause recruiting new fighters and would focus on activities in Africa and in Russia’s neighbor, Belarus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Kornelis
title: Zach Galifianakis Lives in the Cringe
description: The comedian and star of “The Beanie Bubble” feels proud to be an American when he watches “The Simpsons.” These are some of his other favorite things.
content: Zach Galifianakis grew up on Bill Murray, Eddie Murphy, Redd Foxx and David Letterman, but he never sat in front of the family television thinking he wanted to be them. He was more interested in keeping up with his family.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Our Immigration System: ‘A Waste of Talent’
description: Readers point to flaws in U.S. immigration policy. Also: Cruelty at the border; presidential pardon power; A.I. weapons; poor food choices.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Goldbaum
title: ISIS Affiliate Claims Responsibility for Deadly Attack at Rally in Pakistan
description: The death toll from Sunday’s suicide bombing, which targeted a political rally near the border with Afghanistan, rose to at least 54 people, an official said.
content: The Islamic State affiliate in South Asia claimed responsibility on Monday for a suicide bombing in northwest Pakistan that killed dozens of people and injured about 200 more, in the latest bloody sign of the deteriorating security situation in the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic
description: Entries for the week of July 24, 2023.
content: This is Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic, a weekly review of the game that drives me out of my hivemind. In a good way. Sometimes. It is probably also worth mentioning that the Diary is a work of fiction.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ella Quittner
title: Meet the Latest Dining Aesthetic: Darkroom-Core
description: Restaurants across the United States are opting for red lighting as a way to sell intimacy, danger and, sure, food.
content: When David Yun commissioned a custom sign to hang on the wall of his Korean-Southern tapas restaurant, C as in Charlie, he chose LED lighting over neon so that he could change the sign’s color on a whim. Soon, though, the hazy red glow spilling out onto the street became a calling card for the dugout-size restaurant in downtown Manhattan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabe Cohn
title: What’s on TV This Week: ‘Run the Burbs’ and ‘The Trial’
description: A Canadian sitcom debuts on the CW. And a hard-to-find Orson Welles movie airs on TCM.
content: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, July 31 — Aug. 6. Details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: morass
description: This word has appeared in 47 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word morass has appeared in 47 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on May 14 in “What’s the Point of Your 20s? Ask the Patron Saint of Striving Youth” by Emma Goldberg:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: How the Bay Area Became a Mecca of Burmese Cuisine
description: Not so long ago, Burmese food was rare in California. Now dozens of restaurants across San Francisco are cooking samusa soup, mohinga and other favorites.
content: The line to be seated at Mandalay, a decades-old Burmese restaurant in San Francisco, spilled onto the sidewalk on a recent Saturday evening. Inside the festive dining room, customers huddled around rainbow-colored tea leaf salads, spicy noodle soups and flaky parathas served with coconut dip.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: Today’s Top News: Trump Dominates in 2024 Republican Primary Poll, and More
description: Exclusively from New York Times Audio, our new app.
content: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Buckley
title: Two Dead as Heavy Rains Batter Beijing, Putting City on Alert
description: Landslides and flash flooding threatened outer districts of the city, and more than 5,000 residents were evacuated from their homes, the authorities said.
content: Fierce rain and flooding pummeled Beijing on Monday, killing at least two people as the downpour triggered landslides and swept away cars on the city’s outskirts after the authorities issued a red alert for what they warned was the heaviest deluge in years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lia Picard
title: How the Monotony of Sunny California Made New York Shine
description: A couple who mainly thought of the city as a vacation spot learned the hard way that finding an apartment there was anything but boring.
content: For Mehek Khera and Rohit Khilnani, New York was a dream destination. When the couple moved to the United States in 2014 from New Delhi, where they both grew up, they visited the city frequently.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora and Ivan Nechepurenko
title: Small Strikes and Big Ambitions in Ukraine’s Attacks on Russia
description: The stepped-up drone and missile attacks show a will to hamper the Kremlin’s military logistics, and to remind ordinary Russians of the cost of war.
content: Drones have exploded over the gilded domes of the Kremlin. They have hit strategic Russian air bases hundreds of miles from Ukraine. They have struck a Moscow tower that houses several government ministry offices, including the one responsible for the military-industrial complex.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset and Danny Hakim
title: Judge Rejects Trump’s Effort to Short-Circuit Georgia Election Case
description: A Fulton County judge chided Donald Trump’s lawyers for “unnecessary and unfounded legal filings” ahead of indictments expected in mid-August.
content: A Georgia judge forcefully rejected on Monday an effort by former President Donald J. Trump to derail an investigation into attempts by Mr. Trump and his allies to overturn his 2020 election loss in the state — an investigation that is expected to yield indictments in mid-August.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Ilyssa Daly
description: Local Investigations Fellow, 2023
content: Ilyssa is a fellow with the Local Investigations Fellowship at The New York Times. She investigates the unchecked power of sheriffs in rural Mississippi and wrongful conviction cases in New York. Before the fellowship, she reported for the Mississippi Center for Investigative Reporting. Ilyssa is a 2022 graduate of the Toni Stabile Center for Investigative Journalism at Columbia University’s Graduate School of Journalism.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Vrentas
title: N.F.L. Increases Penalties for Sexual Misconduct in Light of Deshaun Watson Case
description: The league can more strictly penalize players for sexual assault involving coercion or threats, and its discipline can take into account patterns of conduct, after a judge who oversaw Watson’s hearing cited the policy’s limits.
content: The N.F.L. has changed its personal conduct policy, expanding the offenses that warrant more serious penalties to include sexual assault “involving threats or coercion” and including “a pattern of conduct” and “offenses that involve planning” as factors that could increase punishment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emiliano Rodríguez Mega
title: Tide of Terror Shifts in Haiti as U.S. Nurse and Her Child Are Abducted
description: This, along with other recent kidnappings, may signal the end of a brief respite, as gangs tighten their grip after being targets of vigilante violence.
content: An American nurse and her daughter have been abducted in Haiti, in the latest kidnapping episode to draw international notice, as a resurgence of violence grips the capital, Port-au-Prince.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser
title: Teen Competitive Cyclist Dies After Being Hit by Driver
description: Magnus White, 17, who competed internationally in cyclocross racing, was killed in Boulder County, Colo., the police said.
content: Magnus White, a 17-year-old “rising star” in competitive cycling, has died after being hit by a car in Colorado while he was training for the world championships, the state police and U.S.A. Cycling, the sport’s governing body, said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff, Rachelle Bonja, Shannon Lin, Alex Stern, Nina Feldman, Liz O. Baylen, Michael Benoist, Marc Georges, Dan Powell, Elisheba Ittoop, Marion Lozano and Chris Wood
title: Italy’s Giorgia Meloni Charts a Path for the Far Right
description: A look at the rise of the Italian prime minister and what it might mean for Europe.
content: Last year, Giorgia Meloni, an Italian far-right politician, became prime minister on an agenda that many feared would mark a radical turn for the country. Now, her visit to the White House last week has bolstered her credentials on the international stage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz and Jesus Jiménez
title: Woman With ‘Doomsday’ Beliefs Gets Life Without Parole in Her Children’s Deaths
description: In May, Lori Vallow Daybell was convicted in the murders of two of her children and of conspiring to murder her husband’s previous wife in Idaho’s district court.
content: An Idaho judge sentenced Lori Vallow Daybell on Monday to three consecutive terms of life in prison without parole for the murders of two of her children and for conspiring to murder her husband’s former wife in a case that drew national attention for what prosecutors described as her “doomsday” beliefs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer and Wesley Parnell
title: Man Fatally Stabbed in Confrontation as He Danced at a Gas Station
description: O’Shae Sibley, 28, was vogueing when men attacked him with gay slurs and told him to stop. A hate crimes task force is investigating.
content: O’Shae Sibley was at a Brooklyn gas station with friends late Saturday night, filling up a car and blasting music by Beyoncé when a group of men approached and told them to stop dancing, according to friends.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheera Frenkel and Ryan Mac
title: Twitter Says It Has Sued Nonprofit That Tracks Hate Speech
description: The Center for Countering Digital Hate said it had received a letter from X, Twitter’s parent company, accusing it of trying to hurt the social platform with its research.
content: Elon Musk has over the last year threatened legal action against tech competitors, employees and people who use Twitter, which he owns. Now he is also taking aim at an organization that studies hate speech and misinformation on social media.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Healy
title: Phoenix’s Month in Hell: A 31-Day Streak of Record Heat Ends
description: A continuous stretch of days reaching or exceeding 110 degrees has filled emergency rooms. On Monday, the city hit 108 degrees, breaking the run, but setting a new, brutal record.
content: Patients with heat stroke and burns from the asphalt are swamping hospitals. Air-conditioners are breaking down at homeless shelters. The medical examiner’s office is deploying trailer-sized coolers to store bodies, for the first time since the early days of Covid.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage
title: Intelligence Board Recommends Curbing F.B.I.’s Power to Use Surveillance Program
description: A presidential advisory panel suggests barring the F.B.I. from using Section 702 to hunt for evidence of crimes without a connection to foreign intelligence.
content: An advisory board to President Biden has recommended limiting the F.B.I.’s ability to use a controversial warrantless surveillance program to hunt for information about Americans, even as it urged lawmakers to renew the law that authorizes it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jordan Gale and Jan Hoffman
title: Scenes From a City That Only Hands Out Tickets for Using Fentanyl
description: Oregon’s experiment to curb overdoses by decriminalizing small amounts of illicit drugs is in its third year, and life has changed for most everyone in the city of Portland.
content: For the past two and a half years, Oregon has been trying an unusual experiment to stem soaring rates of addiction and overdose deaths. People caught with small amounts of illicit drugs for “personal use,” including fentanyl and methamphetamine, are fined just $100 — a sanction that can be waived if they participate in a drug screening and health assessment. The aim is to reserve prosecutions for large-scale dealers and address addiction primarily as a public health emergency.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christiaan Triebert, Haley Willis, Yelyzaveta Kovtun and Alexander Cardia
title: Ukraine’s Other Counteroffensive: Drone Attacks on Russian Soil
description: Officials in Ukraine rarely discuss attacks on targets inside Russia, including Moscow. But video evidence shows an increasing effort to launch long-range strikes inside the country.
content: At least three different Ukrainian-made drones have been used in attacks inside Russia, including Moscow, according to an analysis by The New York Times, indicating a Ukrainian role in strikes that the government in Kyiv has long shrouded in mystery.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: What Should I Wear to Officiate a Wedding?
description: A reader is looking for an outfit that won’t draw attention away from the bride and groom.
content: First, congratulations. Being asked to officiate for a friend’s or relative’s wedding is an honor. In turn, you want to honor the couple and their desires, no matter how weird they may be. Sean Parker, of Napster and Facebook fame, reportedly asked Sir Ian McKellen to officiate at his 2013 “Lord of the Rings”-themed wedding dressed as Gandalf.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: Telling the Truth in a Story-Haunted South
description: The PBS series “Southern Storytellers” reminds us that, despite stereotypes, human beings are infinitely more complex than we often imagine they are.
content: Hanging on my dining-room wall is a photograph taken at the Tennessee State Fair by the Nashville photographer Heidi Ross. A crowd is gathered just beneath a sign marking the entrance to the fair. In the foreground, surrounded by a crush of other people, a Black man holds a small child whose arms are wrapped around his neck. An older child stands beside them. The image captures a sweet, timeless moment amid a swirl of humanity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Juliet Macur
title: A New Era of Soccer Moms Navigates a Rapidly Changing Game
description: Women have long blended motherhood and elite sports. But as soccer expands its support systems, it is also demanding ever more of its players.
content: Julie Ertz was on the clock.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Grant
title: Women Know Exactly What They’re Doing When They Use ‘Weak Language’
description: If you don’t mind, I think I’d like to propose a theory about gender norms. Would that work?
content: “Stop using weak language.” If you’re a woman, you’ve probably gotten this advice from a mentor, a coach or a teacher. If you want to be heard, use more forceful language. If you want a raise or a promotion, demand it. As the saying goes, nice girls don’t get the corner office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicolas Rapold
title: How the Mushroom Cloud Boomed and Bloomed Across American Pop Culture
description: From the Trinity test to “Oppenheimer” and “Asteroid City,” the symbol of nuclear destruction has held multiple but equally disturbing meanings.
content: Witnesses to the Trinity test, the inaugural atomic bomb experiment in 1945 portrayed in “Oppenheimer,” described the billowing blast in various ways. It was said to resemble a chimney, a parasol, a raspberry and — shades of science fiction — a “convoluting brain.” The physicist Enrico Fermi and others likened the furiously rising cloud in the New Mexico desert to a mushroom, and that became the shape now inextricably associated with nuclear explosions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Shop by Taste at This Brooklyn Wine Store
description: Taste56 opens in Dumbo, Brooklyn, with a rotating selection of wine, Kwame Onwuachi and more join Flavors of the Open, and more food news.
content: Taste56, a new wine shop in Dumbo, Brooklyn, takes an uncommon approach. Though you can count on finding white, red, rosé and sparkling wines, they are presented according to what the store calls “palate character,” instead of by geography or varietal. There is a limited inventory of about 300 labels. Consider whites that are bright and crisp, or rich and full; and reds that are round and fleshy, or offer tone and backbone, among others. There are eight categories in all, to determine your preferences. Relating to the name of the store, there are also 56 wines to sample, selected on a rotating basis and with guidance by the staff, to show these characteristics. The significance of 56 is supposedly a preferred proper temperature for storing wine, and also signifies progress in numerology. Sales support water.org, to provide clean water and sanitation in developing countries. The founder, James Fantaci, has worked in wine and hospitality for more than 20 years, and also has sommeliers on staff. The setting, done in wood, stone and marble, is in a building dating from 1892. A wine bar and restaurant, bar56, is coming next door in a few weeks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: Driver Charged For Plowing Car Into Migrant Workers
description: The driver, who claimed he accidentally stepped on the gas, turned himself into the police in Lincolnton, N.C. on Monday.
content: A 68-year-old man who plowed his S.U.V. into a group of six migrant workers outside a Walmart in Lincolnton, N.C. on Sunday turned himself into police on Monday evening, saying he accidentally hit the gas while trying to park and fled in a panic, the police said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elie Levine
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mateo Askaripour
title: What Does It Mean to Be a Witness?
description: In his new story collection, Jamel Brinkley investigates the impact of seeing and being seen.
content: The National Book Award finalist Jamel Brinkley’s sophomore story collection, “Witness,” opens with an epigraph from James Baldwin, describing how thin the line is between a witness and an actor: “Nevertheless,” Baldwin concludes, “the line is real.” But is it? Over the course of 10 splendidly thought-provoking stories — set in Brooklyn and featuring animal rescue volunteers, florists, ghosts, UPS workers and a host of other characters — Brinkley shatters Baldwin’s thesis, masterfully demonstrating that witness and actor are one and the same.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: MONDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Davenport
title: Heat Is Costing the U.S. Economy Billions in Lost Productivity
description: From meatpackers to home health aides, workers are struggling in sweltering temperatures and productivity is taking a hit.
content: As much of the United States swelters under record heat, Amazon drivers and warehouse workers have gone on strike in part to protest working conditions that can exceed 100 degrees Fahrenheit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Richtel
title: Is It an E-Bike, or a Motorcycle for Children?
description: With a throttle and no pedals, Super73’s new “electric balance bike” blurs the lines of regulation and safety. “No license, registration or insurance required,” its marketing promises.
content: LeGrand Crewse, co-founder and chief executive of Super73, recently showed off the company’s latest product, a diminutive motorized bike called the K1D. Aimed at riders 4 years old and up, the vehicle lacks pedals, in the spirit of a training bicycle, and has a throttle. The company calls the K1D an “electric balance bike.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Marine Drill Instructor Acquitted in Recruit’s Death
description: A military jury found Staff Sgt. Steven Smiley not guilty of negligent homicide and other charges in the death of Pfc. Dalton Beals, 19, during a grueling training exercise in 2021.
content: A military jury has found that a Marine Corps drill instructor was not guilty of negligent homicide and other charges in the death of a 19-year-old recruit during a grueling training exercise on Parris Island, S.C., in 2021.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $2 Million Homes in California
description: A shingled home in Altadena, a golf-course retreat in Costa Mesa and a ‘Tree House’ in San Luis Obispo.
content: This house is at the base of the San Gabriel Mountains, a few minutes’ drive from popular hiking trails. It is less than half a mile from a playground and equestrian facilities at Loma Alta Park and from a stretch of Lincoln Avenue with a coffee shop and a garden center.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chang Che
title: Missing Sailor’s Boat Is Found Off the Mexican Coast
description: Donald Lawson, 41, of Baltimore was training for a solo sailing trip around the world when he left Acapulco on July 5. His capsized boat, the Defiant, was found in the Pacific on July 24.
content: The capsized boat of Donald Lawson, a sailor from Baltimore who disappeared in the Pacific Ocean over two weeks ago, has been found off the coast of Mexico, his wife said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg
title: Extensive Minefields Impede Ukraine’s Counteroffensive, Military Analysts Say.
description: Russia has been using antitank weaponry against the Ukrainian forces’ mine clearing vehicles, an analyst said.
content: Extensive minefields laid by Russian forces are proving among the toughest obstacles facing Ukraine’s counteroffensive, and the tools that Kyiv’s military has for removing them are inadequate, according to experts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Nehamas
title: Trailing Trump, DeSantis Unveils Economic Plan Slamming ‘Failed Elites’
description: Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida introduced a 10-point economic plan geared toward the blue-collar voters with whom he has struggled to resonate.
content: Attempting to meld his “anti-woke” politics with economic policy, Gov. Ron DeSantis on Monday unveiled a plan that he claimed took on corporate interests, business elites, federal government bureaucrats and foreign trade relations — forces he blamed for derailing the prosperity of American families.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Fahy
title: One co-host is out. Can Sam Kerr and Australia avoid the same fate?
description: The pressure is on for Australia. The Australians entered this Women’s World Cup as co-hosts looking to win the tournament on home soil, and quickly struggled.
content: The pressure is on for Australia. The Australians entered this Women’s World Cup as co-hosts looking to win the tournament on home soil, and quickly struggled.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raja Abdulrahim and Hwaida Saad
title: Clashes in a Palestinian Refugee Camp in Lebanon Kill 11
description: Rival factions have been fighting for three days, at times with heavy weaponry, in the densely populated Ein al-Hilweh camp in the coastal city of Sidon, south of Beirut.
content: Rival factions clashed in a Palestinian refugee camp in southern Lebanon for a third straight day on Monday in an eruption of violence that has left at least 11 people dead since it began.
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: July 31, 2023
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, July 31, 2023.
content: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gary J. Bass
title: What Jack Smith Knows
description: It is always difficult and risky to prosecute national leaders with some popularity among their people.
content: Donald Trump openly flatters foreign autocrats such as Vladimir V. Putin and Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman of Saudi Arabia, and in many ways Mr. Trump governed as authoritarians do around the globe: enriching himself, stoking ethnic hatreds, seeking personal control over the courts and the military, clinging to power at all costs. So it is especially fitting that he has been notified that he may soon be indicted on charges that he tried to overturn the 2020 election, by an American prosecutor who is deeply versed in investigating the world’s worst tyrants and war criminals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Nereim
title: Saudi Arabia Will Host Talks About Ukraine’s Peace Plan, Diplomats Say
description: Envoys from nations including the United States, Brazil, China and India have been invited, but it was not clear who would attend, the diplomats said.
content: Saudi Arabia will host talks on Ukraine’s peace plan with several other countries this weekend in the coastal city of Jeddah, three foreign diplomats in the kingdom have said.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Cross-Tabs: July 2023 Times/Siena Poll of the Race for Republican Nominee for President
description: Donald Trump leads the field among the likely Republican primary electorate, pulling 54 percent of the vote, according to a poll conducted by The New York Times and Siena College from July 23 to 27, 2023.
content: Donald Trump leads the field among the likely Republican primary electorate, pulling 54 percent of the vote, according to a poll conducted by The New York Times and Siena College from July 23 to 27, 2023.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Audio Stories are Redefining Pleasure for Women
description: Apps like Dipsea and Quinn have become popular destinations, particularly for some women who find them safe spaces to explore their sexuality.

title: The Country That Bombs Its Own People
description: Visual evidence, data and interviews show that the Myanmar military’s campaign of terror, which began after a coup sparked widespread resistance, is getting worse.
content: Visual evidence, data and interviews show that the Myanmar military’s campaign of terror, which began after a coup sparked widespread resistance, is getting worse.

description: The last sentence of many books can stick with a reader for years. Can you identify the five novels in this short quiz?
content: The last sentence of many books can stick with a reader for years. Can you identify the five novels in this short quiz?

title: 6 Takeaways From Political Ads in Iowa
description: With the Iowa caucuses less than six months away, G.O.P. candidates are ramping up ad spending in the state.

title: Flash Floods and Landslides Sweep Chinese Cities
